To the Editor: After ''Sometimes, Smaller is Better'' (Aug. 20) by John Rosenthal, and ''larger is better when it's raining'' (the letter from Seymour Goldberg, Sept. 3), I feel a little like Goldilocks. As far as cruise ships go, small may suit some and large others, but for me our midsize ship was just right for Alaska.

My husband and I took a two-week Elderhostel tour of the Inside Passage in August. There were 130 hostelers among the 700 passengers on our ship, the Universe Explorer, which has eight decks, five lounges, a 200-seat theater, a computer center and a very small exercise room.

The ship was small enough to get so close to a glacier that we could hear the crack as it calved. It was big enough to be comfortable and stable and to have entertainment by fine classical instrumentalists and singers, plus a dance band in the evening.

The University of Alaska at Fairbanks provided us with experienced leaderswho took us close to Alaska's wildlife, its natural beauty and, perhaps most important to me, a better understanding of the people who lived there first and those who came later.
